content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" is introduced to exclude space-related income from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and other related amounts like interest or royalties. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and other related amounts like interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts received with respect to production or service. There are exceptions for telecommunications services, services provided by satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Wages received by employees are also exempt. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from products or services produced in outer space. Space-related income is determined by proportional allocation between space-based and earth-based activities. The term "produced" encompasses various processes such as creation, fabrication, development, manufacturing, extraction, processing, curing, and aging. Additionally, any product manufactured in outer space is excluded from tariffs. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal tariffs, excises, imposts, and duties if launched from and returned to the United States or manufactured at a facility in outer space owned by U.S. persons. Benefits under this act will phase out gradually after December 31, 2014. The term 'space-based business' refers to a business with gross receipts primarily from space-related income. Rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for aggregation. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation must be acquired at original issue by a taxpayer from a qualified space company. Qualified stock must be acquired at original issue by the taxpayer from a qualified space company in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services. The stock must be in a corporation meeting active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business. Section 1202(e) outlines that qualified stock must be acquired from a space-based business C corporation. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply to stock purchases by the corporation. If the issuer of the stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, tax credits may be recaptured. This section does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2013. The section outlines rules for the space company investment credit, including the termination of the credit for stock acquired after December 31, 2013. Amendments are made to the general business credit section to include the space company investment credit. Conforming amendments are also made to include the space company investment credit in relevant sections of the tax code. The space company investment credit rules are outlined, with amendments made to include the credit in the general business credit section and relevant sections of the tax code. Additionally, a new paragraph is added regarding the determination of the credit under section 45I(a). The amendments made by this section apply to costs incurred after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a new section is added for the exclusion of gains from the sale of stock of qualified space corporations. Gross income excludes gain on the sale of stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space with at least 90% of expenses related to this activity. The text chunk discusses the exclusion of certain corporations from the definition of a qualified space corporation, specifically those providing services described in section 139B(b)(2). A clerical amendment is also mentioned in relation to the table of sections for part I of subchapter P of the Code. The exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
